I will be on the lookout for a crock for some sauerkraut...my hubby's parents make this but now I have a stronger urge to try it out.Interesting, intellectual and inspiring! Well written and well documented.On a final note...it was peanut free so it's safe for everyone. ;)

This was a good book if you're interested in the anatomy of cooking. Michael Pollan is one of my favorite food writers and I always enjoy his books, this one as well. However, this was a little too in depth for me.Michael explores the four realms of cooking in this book, Fire, Water, Air and Earth. For Fire, he uses whole hog barbeque. For Water, he explores braising. For air, his example is baking bread. For Earth he uses fermentation. Basically, he breaks all of these cooking methods down to the smallest elements and builds on it.My final thought on this book is that it was interesting, but if your not really into cooking/food then this book may be too much for you.

In his latest book, Cooked, Michael Pollan serves up another bestseller that looks at the relationships between us and the food we eat. Struck by the realization that ‚Äúthe less cooking we were doing in our own lives, the more that food and its vicarious preparation transfixed us,‚Äù Pollan sets out to explore the art of cooking for himself.Cooked reads like a how-to book for the uninitiated in the kitchen while still providing plenty of more detailed analysis for seasoned cooks. Divided into chapters based on the four classical elements ‚Äì Earth, Water, Air and Fire ‚Äì Pollan personally explores the world of cooking where ‚Äúthe stuff of nature gets transformed into the things we eat and drink.‚ÄùIn each chapter, Pollan learns about a corresponding cooking style: in Fire, he gets grilling lessons from a North Carolina barbecue pit master; in Water, he masters braises; in Air, he experiments with bread baking as he seeks to perfect the perfect sourdough loaf; and finally, in Earth, he explores various types of fermentation including pickling, cheese making and home brewing.Along the way, each of his teachers ‚Äì from ‚Äúthe cheese nun‚Äù with a Ph.D. in microbiology to the ‚Äúmost famous fermentor in America‚Äù ‚Äì is whole-heartedly devoted to his or her craft and, in the end, getting a glimpse into their lives and work is half the fun of the book.I‚Äôve been a Michael Pollan fan since I first cracked the spine of The Botany of Desire more than a decade ago, but even I‚Äôll admit, there are a few points in the narrative where even the most devout reader‚Äôs eyes may start to glaze over‚Ä¶ like when Pollan gets mired in the details of the ‚Äúall-important Lactobacillus sanfranciscensis‚Äù microbe. But only briefly. Because along with straight-up cool science, he also mixes into his narrative a bit of history, art and literature along with a dash of religion (‚Äúbread‚Ä¶ is an everyday proof of the possibility of transcendence‚Äù and sex for good measure (‚Äúa cheese that stinks ‚Äì of manure, of sex ‚Äì offers a relatively safe way for us to flirt with forbidden desires‚Äù).As in his previous books, Pollan extolls the ills (literally) of processed foods and cautions against our over-reliance on corporations, ‚Äúwhose ‚Äòdead food‚Äô is damaging our health and ‚Äòhomogenizing‚Äô our experience.‚ÄùWhen asked why we don‚Äôt spend more time preparing our own meals, apparently most people claim a lack of time. But Pollan points out that, ‚Äúin the last decade or so, we‚Äôve all found two hours a day to be on line outside of work.‚Äù So what gives?Another entire book could be devoted to answering that question, but Pollan doesn‚Äôt take on that job in Cooked. Instead, he argues that we would all do well to start getting reacquainted with our kitchens because ‚Äúcooking is one of the most interesting and worthwhile things we humans do.‚ÄùWhile it may be cheaper and easier to rely on others to provide for our basic needs, ‚Äúto live that way comes at a price, not least to our sense of competence and independence.‚Äù We are so disconnected from the makers of our food, Pollan argues, that we stop thinking about what is actually in the food we eat or where it comes from, much less the labor, money or energy it took to get it onto our plate. Worst of all, we forget that ‚Äúwhat presents itself to us in the marketplace as a product is in truth a web of relationships between people‚Ä¶ and all the other species on which we still depend.‚Äù (Yes, even bacteria.)In the end, Cooked turns out to be a commentary on the way we live. It‚Äôs true, as in his past books, that Pollan is critical of capitalism, and in particular consumerism, as the downfall of democracy and independence in its most literal sense. The antidote (or part of it, anyway) that he offers up here is cooking. To cook, he says, is to reclaim a bit of independence, and perhaps a bit of pride as well. It‚Äôs what separates us from the rest of the natural world and, paradoxically, also what keeps us connected to it.It is also an invitation to modern society (that‚Äôs you and me) to reconnect with the world. It‚Äôs true that few of us have the luxury of spending hours in the kitchen making all of our meals from scratch, but even small culinary contributions help us to reconnect with the natural world around us. As Pollan himself admits, ‚ÄúThe most important thing I learned ‚Ä¶ is how cooking implicates us in a whole web of social and ecological relationships: with plants and animals, with the soil, with farmers, with the microbes both inside and outside our bodies, and, of course, with the people our cooking nourishes and delights.‚Äù And he invites us ‚Äúto alter, however slightly, the ratio between production and consumption‚Äù in our lives.This, he believes, can make a difference. After trying his hand at home brewing, Pollan says, ‚ÄúThe beer in that bottle, I‚Äôm reminded as soon as I brew it myself, ultimately comes not from a factory, but from nature ‚Äì from a field of barley snapping in the wind, from a hops vine clambering over a trellis, from a host of invisible microbes feasting on sugars.‚ÄùSo, if preparing our own home-cooked meals makes us think just a little bit more about the world around us and how, ultimately, we all depend on one another to survive, then certainly a little time with a knife and cutting board won‚Äôt hurt anyone.For novices in the kitchen ‚Äì or first-time Pollan readers ‚Äì Cooked is sure to whet your appetite. For the rest of us, it is the continuation of an ongoing commentary on food, nature and modern society that will not fail to satisfy.

It's difficult to rate a book which was very enjoyable to read, but fraught with quirks of Pollan's writing style and ideology. I'll write this review as a "compliment sandwich." To begin: The chapters on Barbeque (Fire) and Bread (Air) were particularly strong and interesting. I enjoyed the attention he gave to food research at UC Davis, and was glad to see him visit some interesting operations in Yolo County.That being said...Pollan went on several rants only tenuously connected to his topics. Notably, his nostalgia for an agrarian/culinary past that, to use the phrase of Jello Biafra "never existed." Pollan seems oblivious to his own level of wealth and privelege. He emphasizes that he braises "cheap" pieces of meat. Has he compared the price of a brisket to chicken? bologna? a can of beans? He spends days at a time on breads, insisting that he can "get writing done" in between turns and rises. Not everyone is a freelance writer, buddy. Try making a braise and two sourdoughs a week working 9-5.My final criticism is his love of "artisans" while scoffing at anything remotely automated. The problem is that for artisans (of food and everything else) it's a labor of love. An independent baker selling high-end sourdough might be carrying on a food tradition or whatever, but the forklift operator, truck driver, QC specialist, etc. at the Wonder-bread plant he's so quick to dismiss have mentally and physically demanding jobs, with some security, benefits, and disposable income that the starving artist-baker lacks. Does Pollan really envision a bucolic future of nothing but cottage industries? Who would have the income to buy his books?The joke's on him, I took it out of the library.In conclusion- Pollan is an entertaining and gripping writer who has sought out some very interesting characters in the American foodscape. Parts of this book rehash "Omnivore's Dilema," but hey. What can you do? If this were a bad book, I wouldn't have finished it. It's honestly good writing, somewhat choppy, and somewhat obsessive about certain details (raising dough) while ignoring others (Pollan's wealth, and location in the foodie Island of the Bay Area.)

Where has our love gone, Michael? This is the fourth of your books that I've read, which is somewhat fitting, considering your obsession with that number. Second Nature: four seasons, Omnivore's Dilemma: four meals, Botany of Desire: four plants, and with this book four methods of food preparation. I was really excited about a new book from you, as I really enjoyed those three earlier books, despite your tendency to ramble and repeat. When an acquaintance told me how much she enjoyed this book (her first experience with you), I quickly recommended the others and offered to swap her OD for this one. And yet...somehow I just can't get into it. Maybe it's that you're again preaching your slow food message and I've already joined the choir. Maybe it's the current heat wave that makes the subject of cooking less appealing. Maybe it's my stack of novels and lighter non-fiction driving me to distraction. Whatever the cause(s), I'm going to return this copy to the owner (since I've had it for three or four weeks already) and track down a library copy later when cooking and, let's be honest...you, Michael, sound more appealing.Update: it took me almost 7 years, but I finally finished this book! This time, I started with the section on yeast breads, focusing on sourdough. I've experimented with sourdough a couple times since reading Sourdough (and started a new one after finishing the book), so I had more connection to Pollan's experiences than the previous sections. The final section, in which he discusses fermentation (of vegetables, cheese, and alcohol) was also really interesting, especially the American-born nun making traditional cheese in a French convent. For me, the second half of the book was much stronger.

Michael Pollan has written another book about food; this time he researches the history of cooking. He focuses on cooking using the classic elements of fire, water, air, and earth.The section on fire focuses almost exclusively on smoking pork, which is something I enjoy doing. For those of you that have never enjoyed barbeque or smoking, you might not connect with this section like I did. Smoked pork (and chicken) is so good, it is worth the effort to try to perfect your efforts! Take a look at my video on smoking Boston Butts: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2U2--A...I have videos on smoking chicken, salmon filets, and ribs; smoked food is so good and it is fun to connect with nature to prepare food!In the section on cooking with water, Pollan uses a pot to slow cook various delicious dishes. He talked about the time and effort to cook slowly on the stovetop. I had to wonder why he didn't even try using a crockpot or slow cooker! Nonetheless, all of the food sounded really good!The section on air focused on making bread and I almost wanted to make a loaf myself, but then I remembered how addictive bread out of the oven tastes! It was very interesting!Lastly, Pollan focused on "earth" as an element of cooking. Any guess what that could be? I never would have guessed, but it is fermentation. This was my least favorite section because I don't drink, but it was interesting to listen to how Pollan made his own beer. There are many health benefits to eating foods like yogurt that use something like fermentation to grow the cultures. While I eat yogurt every day, I am too much of a wimp to eat the other foods Pollan highlighted.Of course, Pollan could not resist discussing how many people no longer cook--or they heat prepared food and call that cooking. I found all of that fascinating because I do not buy many prepared foods; however, I buy more than I thought!I listened to this audiobook while gardening and loved it!

‚ÄúI found that, much like gardening, most cooking manages to be agreeably absorbing without being too demanding intellectually. It leaves plenty of mental space for daydreaming and reflection.‚Äù ‚Äï Michael Pollan, Cooked: A Natural History of Transformation In Cooked Michael Pollan stays close to his food roots. Similar in theme to: Omnivore's Dilema (Four Meals), In Defense of Food (Food Manifesto), Botany of Desire (Four Plants), Food Rules (Owner's Manual for Food), and Second Nature (Growing Food).Cooked is just another branch on the Phylogenetic food tree for the Pollan's Omnivore, me thinks. Unless, of course, Pollan is going to delve into the proper way to digest, poop, or compost your waste. And... he might just. I am neither a Pollan lover or hater. I've read a bunch of his stuff because it is fast and rather tasty. The problem with Pollan is reading too much of him. His books are a bit full of roughage and eventually too much of his raw idealism or fiber-rich localism gets to you. I think that is the problem with idealists and their genius (genus?). No one can quite live upto the expectations. There just isn't that many locally grown mushrooms, or farmer's markets, or grass-fed organic beef. But education about farming, feasting, and cooking gives us a better sense of both the idea and the real. As long as we are aware of the costs of the way we eat and the way we cook, we are better than we started. The probelm comes in when we believe ALL the hype. As long as you can remain pragmatic about food and Pollan, reading him is a good thing.

Oh my. If there ever was a more tedious and odious exercise in navel gazing, I'd be impressed.I must confess I am baffled by this book. Who is the audience? Is it local foodies who are already converted? In which case, why on earth must the author keep telling us again and again and again how awesome cooking is? We get it, we're the choir, quit your preaching.Or perhaps the audience is the mass produced shrink-wrap microwave toting loner. In which case, hearing someone pontificate on and on and on about the joys of combining heat with edible things is also pointlessly preachy, and Mr Pollan does an abysmal sales job here.The problem is that Mr Pollan has completely and totally run out of things to say. As a result, this book is basically reworking the same sentence over and over again using different combinations of words. So to save the hapless potential victim from having to wade through a few hundred pages of tedium, I'd suggest instead spending the next hour rearranging any subset of these words into as many variations as you can:Heavenly, nature, cooking, is, god, primitive man, plants, aroma, animal sacrifice, producesHour over? You're welcome, I just saved you many more hours of your precious time. You can spend the remaining 5-6 you have left over from not reading this book staring blankly into space, it'll be more meaningful and more likely to result in food related insights.

Don't we all know how to make spaghetti sauce. That how to make bolonaise was a revelation to the author was more telling of him than other informational bits. I have a friend whose husband doesn't know how to turn on his oven. That said, I agree 100 percent with the author about the practice of making meals as being healthy and a good practice. I think he is a fine author and I look forward to his next book. But beware, if you eat enough Carolina BBQ you will end up looking like a hog farmer:)

While I do not eat, and do not advocate eating, many of the items described in this book (meat, cheese, wine...), I am still fascinated by the history of cooking and the processes involved. I really enjoyed the theme of looking at how we use different elements to cook (fire, water, air, earth). It was an enjoyable way to think about the complexity of a task which we used to do daily, but in which industrial societies have been eschewing.
I could go on and on, but it's simple. I love Michael Pollan and everything he has to say.

I have been a big fan of Michael Pollan's books for many years now. So, when this book was published, I really looked forward to reading it. I love his ability to take the science and technical aspects of food and nutrition and make them fascinating.I thought that it was quite appropriate that I read this book during a holiday centered around cooking and eating: Thanksgiving. I love cooking for our family, and I try hard to share that love with our girls, teaching them the simple concepts that I know and showing them how easy it is for a parent who works out of the home to prepare a home-cooked meal using little to no prepared foods. This book really shows the genesis of human cooking and the emotional and primal urges behind what and how we cook. In four different parts (fire, water, air, and earth), he describes different ways we engage with food. I'm not sure what happened - I read the first three parts in the span of just one day, but then I was overwhelmed with other books that I needed to read (for my book club or because they were coming due), and this book was pushed to the side for over a month. Finally, I decided I needed to finish it (I'm sure it's coming due soon!) and I tackled the fourth part in one day. So, while it looks like I took my sweet time, I just had a big break in between.interesting quotes:"Once cooking allowed us to expand our cognitive capacity at the expense of our digestive capacity, there was no going back: Our big brains and tiny guts now depended on a diet of cooked food." (p. 7)"...it will come as no surprise that the decline in home cooking closely tracks the rise in obesity and all the chronic diseases linked to diet." (p. 8)"Killing and cooking a large animal has never been anything but an emotionally freighted and spiritually charged endeavor." (p. 13)"For is there any practice less selfish, any labor less alienated, any time less wasted, than preparing something delicious and nourishing for people you love?" (p. 23)"Cooking puts several kinds of distance between the brutal facts of the matter (dead animal for dinner) and the dining-room table set with crisp linens and polished silver." (pp. 50-51)"...the braise or stew - and particularly the braise or stew of meat that's been cut into geometric cubes and rendered tender by long hours in the pot - represents a deeper sublimation, or forgetting, of the brutal reality of this particular transaction among species." (p. 54)[Samin Nosrat] "'Great cooking is all about the three 'p's: patience, presence, and practice,' she told me at one point. Samin is a devoted student of yoga and she sees important parallels in the mental habits demanded by both disciplines." (p. 141)"If all cooking is a process of transforming the stuff of nature into culture, boiling achieves a more complete transformation of the animal being eaten by (among other things) eliminating any trace of blood." (p. 156)"Who knows what is cooking down there in that scary pot? Bubbling away beneath the murky swamp of sauce might be eye of newt or tail of rat. All pot cooking is occult in some degree, the precise identity of the ingredients hidden from inspection, more or less illegible. 'Mystery meat' is how children refer to it, and rightly so." (p. 159) [our girls often ask what is cooking, and to defray the potential 'ewww, I don't like that'-kind of comment, I ususually just say 'pickled pigs feet. They know that isn't the truth, but they still haven't gotten a satisfactory answer.]"Umami, I realized, is the quasi-secret heart and soul of almost every braise, stew, and soup.I say 'secret' because umami works in somewhat mysterious ways, at least compared with sweet, salt, bitter, and sour. Encountered in the purified form of monosodium glutamate (MSG), glutamate doesn't taste particularly good, or for that matter much like anything at all. To work its magic, umami needs to be in the company of other ingredients. A bit like salt, glutamate seems to italicize the taste of foods, but, unlike salt, it doesn't have an instantly recognizable taste of its own." (p. 169)...the time that people used to spend cooking had a substantial, invisible, and generally positive effect on the way that they and their families ate." (p/ 190)"The study found that when we don't have to cook meals ourselves we eat more of them. As the amount of time Americans spend cooking has dropped by half, the number of meals Americans eat in a day has climbed; since 1977, we've added roughly half a meal's worth of food to our daily intake, most of it in the form of secondary eating." (pp. 191-192)"It seems to me that one of the great luxuries of life at this point is to be able to do one thing at a time, one thing to which you give yourself wholeheartedly.Unitasking." (p. 195)"There's something about a slow-cooked dish that militates against eating it quickly, and we took our time with dinner. Isaac told us about his day; we told him about ours. For the first time all day, it felt like we were all on the same page, and though it would be overstating things to credit that feeling entirely to the delicious braise, it would also be wrong to think that eating the same thing from the same pot, this weeknight communion of the casserole, had nothing to do with it, either." (p. 201)"Some researchers attribute the increase in gluten intolerance and celiac disease to the fact that modern breads no longer receive a lengthy fermentation. The organic acids produced by the sourdough culture also seem to slow our bodies' absorption of the sugars in white flour, reducing the dangerous spikes of insulin that refined carbohydrates can cause." (p. 229)"Going back to ancient Rome, the shade of the bread you could afford precisely indicated your social standing; to know one's place, Juvenal wrote, is 'to know the color of one's bread.' Some historians and anthropologists have suggested the prestige of white flour might also have had a racist tint to it." (p. 256)Sandor Katz: "Did you know you have more bacterial cells in your body than human cells? By a factor of ten! Most of the DNA we're carrying around is microbial DNA, not human. Which raises an interesting question: Who exactly are we?" (p. 300)"One USDA scientist went so far as to claim that there has never been a documented case of food-borne illness from eating fermented vegetables." (p. 312)"For some of us, the deleterious changes to our gut microflora begin at birth, the moment when we are first inoculated with the microbes that will accompany us through life. In utero, our bodies are sterile, but the microbially messy process of vaginal birth exposes the baby to a set of bacteria that immediately begin to colonize its body. Children born by Cesarean section, a far more hygienic process, take much longer to populate their intestinal tract, and never acquire the same assortment of bugs. Some researchers believe this could help explain the higher rates of allergies, asthma, and obesity observed in children born by Cesarean." (pp. 329-330)"Arguing over which culture has the more disgusting delicacy is never going to be very productive. What's interesting here is that so many cultures seem to have one powerful, smelly food that they prize with as much fervor as other cultures despise it...And, just as curiously, the devotees of these strong ferments (or spicy foods) frequently take pleasure in the fact that people from other cultures can't easily choke them down. One of the things a food can do for people is to help define them as a group - we are the people who like to eat rotted shark. It could be that the success of this self-definition depends on other people finding the very same food inedible or disgusting. In the same way that disgust can be used to draw lines between humans and other animals, it can also help draw lines between cultures." (pp. 369-370)"Alcohol is probably the most social drug we humans have. It takes cooperation to produce it, and it is commonly consumed in the company of others." (p. 396)  "The Dionysian magic of fermentation was at once a property of nature and of the human soul, and one could unlock the other." (p. 400)

"...cheese was not so much an invention as a discovery." Yet another masterpiece by Pollan, Cooked is an anthropological, sociological, ethnographical, and humorous narrative just as engulfing as his others. Whether you are a professional chef or a lover of food, this book makes you hungry...for more.
How is Brandon Sanderson considered a better writer by reviews than Michael Pollan?

Pollan has an easy, friendly, and persuasive writing style that managed to draw me away from another book I'd pre-ordered in two formats when Cooked happened to show up on the library hold shelf on the other book's release date.He's best when he's describing his own experiences or describing micro-science to a layman; I found him a little less convincing and slightly on the side of pretentious when he indulged in wide-scale anthropological musings or symbolism along the lines of the four elements he uses to organize this book: fire (barbecue), water (braises), air (bread), and earth (fermented foods, like sauerkraut and beer). I would've been totally fine with section headings with the food name.I was actually surprised to discover that he wasn't already an expert cook; one of his previous books, The Omnivore's Dilemma, had so incisively made the case for eating in a wholesome manner that I'd assumed he had mastered this skill. But this book is the story of his education in various culinary arenas, and as he manages gain tutelage under acclaimed pit masters and bakers, he--and I--became engrossed in his teachers' personal stories and the philosophies that brought them to the mastery of their crafts. (Or the philosophies that developed because of those crafts.)Thus you meet such interesting folks as the "cheese nun," who managed to get the state health inspector to stand down in an otherwise shrill war about raw milk...by a scientific experiment:A nun's habit and a Ph.D. in microbiology--the abbey sent her to the University of Connecticut so that she might better be able to defend her cheese, both from pathogens and from public health authorities--are an unbeatable combination, and, so far at least, the FDA has thought better than to mess with Sister No√´lla, even as the agency has come down hard on many other raw-milk cheese makers.This lovely sly humor is on display several times, often parenthetically, such as when he describes a 300-year-old fermentation pit:The breadfruit in it had been reduced to a sour mush, but it was reported to be "still in edible condition." (You first.)It was interesting how each type of training received different treatment in Pollan's words. The whole pig barbecue ended up making me think more about the sweaty insanity of the chopping block afterward, while trying to feed thousands of hungry people; the year of weekly braising lessons felt prosaic, free of any sudden revelations, although Pollan admits to using what he learned here the most frequently afterward. His description of the bread-making process was utterly engrossing to me (a non-baker from a rice-centric culture), from how he coaxed the starter yeast to the shaping of the dough. His satisfaction rose almost palpably off the bread as he broke the crust of his efforts.And although he dips into scientific explanations whenever he sees fit, pointing out the chemical processes behind caramelization or the nutrients that separate whole wheat flour from white, he delves most deeply into the question of human interaction with internal bacteria: the gut microflora that actually does a lot of the work in keeping us healthy, and how hyper-sanitized environments and antibiotics can devastate this balance. Mary Roach also devotes some time to this in Gulp, and I anticipate a popular science book on the subject soon. Pollan himself doesn't subscribe to the "kombucha will cure AIDS!" line of "let the bacteria grow wild and free!" thinking, but he does make a strong case for eating less sterile food.Note: To his credit, Pollan does acknowledge head-on the gender imbalance that tends to accompany kitchen duties, without letting the discussion devour the book. In general I found him to be cognizant of the larger issues lying behind his personal quest, whether it be food industry lobbying power or cultural values, but touching upon them only gently.Quite a satisfying read, although I think it's best viewed more along memoirish lines than the sort of societal revolution hinted at in The Omnivore's Dilemma. And the ending was more powerful than those of many novels I've read.

‚ÄúCooking is all about connection, I've learned, between us and other species, other times, other cultures (human and microbial both), but, most important, other people. Cooking is one of the more beautiful forms that human generosity takes; that much I sort of knew. But the very best cooking, I discovered, is also a form of intimacy.‚ÄùThis is the third book that I have read by Pollan. He started by writing about gardening and naturally moved on to food and cooking. I started with The Omnivore‚Äôs Dilemma and skipped the gardening books. (I really should go back to those ‚Äì I like reading about gardening even though I don‚Äôt like gardening much.) All three of these books about food have been interesting and enlightening.When I did my review for The Omnivore‚Äôs Dilemma, I wrote, ‚ÄúFor me this is what makes a good read. I get immersed in the book; I learn new things and for at least some of the time I am thinking about the book and author even when I am not reading the book.‚Äù That was true for this book as well. I listened to this and since it took more than thirteen hours, it was with me for a long time. I enjoyed thinking through Pollan‚Äôs theories about how the four elements reflect the four ways of cooking and meeting several chefs, bakers, cheesmakers and brewers. I will look at cooking a bit differently because of this book.
3.5 stars and only because I hold Pollen to a higher standard and liked his other books more.

This book has made me rethink many aspects of cooking. Especially how I cook. It is divided into 4 parts, fire, water, air, and earth all corresponding to specific methods of cooking. The fire portion was probably my least favorite and has made it even less likely that I will take up roasting a pig. And some of his comments about the pork industry, though brief, have made me pass up the pork section altogether at the grocery store. Enlightening are his observations about how we perceive the time it takes to cook and based on our perception that it is laborious and time consuming we have surrendered our meal preparation duties to large industry, an industry that has neither health nor quality at the core of its interests. And he counters that quick meal preparation is not so quick and the time it took him and his family to defrost and cook frozen meals he could easily have made a braise. Pollan also reveals what goes into a loaf of bread and how the baker‚Äôs pursuit of a light loaf full of air has caused a whole wheat industry to subvert the nutrition of the grain. My favorite part of this book however is the fourth and final part ‚Äì earth which he dedicates to the art of fermenting. The whole concept of food decaying and then being turned into something not only particular to region and culture but actually good for the human gut is very intriguing and he does a great job of exploring what is going on with this process on a micro level. Also included in the portion of the book is cheese making. His works with the nun, Sister Noella, who makes cheese the old fashion way in large oak barrels contrary to FDA regulations and contrary to our own ideas of what will make the safest product to eat. But Sister Noella has done her homework (doctorate in microbiology) and can prove that the oak barrels produce a more stable product than the steel barrels used by the rest of the industry. While I wish Pollan would have put some of the same time and effort into the cheese portion of the book that he did for the pork roasting, he does do just enough where one will want to know more. In fact I think most of the book does and excellent job of whetting the appetite so to speak for a real discussion about our notions of convenience, health, taste, and how we cook. I really hope this fans the small flames for the trend to cook at home. It really is better in every way.

I thought I liked Michael Pollan's writing. Have I changed, or has he?This book had some good content, but Pollan's writing really got in the way. It read like the writing of someone who has gotten a little overconfident in the value of their interests and opinions to others, someone who loves their own writing a little too much, someone who was perhaps reluctant to seek the editing help they really needed.My problems with Pollan's writing are:1) He hammers his points home to the extent of sounding pedantic and condescending. Yes, cooking is the thing that separates us humans from animals, I get it. Now you're telling it to me another twenty times in twenty not-different-enough ways?2) Indulgent digression - between this and point #2, the book could have been cut down by about 100 pages into a much stronger, poignant book.3) Overwrought sentences and flimsy connections drawn between food and other things. Do the following excerpts not make you want to kind of throw up a little of the beautiful braise you just ate:"...it is the very allusiveness of cooked food that appeals to us, as indeed that same quality does in poetry or music or art. We gravitate toward complexity and metaphor, it seems, and putting fire to meat, or fermenting fruit and grain, gives us both: more sheer sensory information and, specifically, sensory information that, like metaphor, points away from the here and now. This sensory metaphor--this stands for that--is one of the most important transformations of nature wrought by cooking. And so a piece of crisped pigskin becomes a densely allusive poem of flavors...""Elation, effervescence, elevation, levity, inspiration: air words all, alveolated with vowels, leavening the dough of everyday life."Ick. And that's only one of several times he "cleverly" uses "leaven." We get it, Pollan. It's a bread word and you applied it to stuff that isn't bread.Just so tiresome, but I stuck with it because I liked the idea of the book, and some of the content was good. The discussion of bacterial flora did a good job of addressing a new topic in food and health, for example. But this might be the last Pollan book I read.

I enjoy cooking and eating, but I don't read Michael Pollan's books ‚Äì this is at least my third ‚Äì for the food. If so, I would never have finished this. I am a vegetarian, and the first half of Cooked is about barbecue and braising ‚Äì the smells of cooking pig flesh! ‚Äì so not my favorite.I read Pollan's books for his curiosity. They are as much or more about the science of cooking and the philosophy of living. You have to be ready to geek out about everything that you come across. You need to be willing to stop and question all sorts of things: nutrition, chemistry, history, politics, gender.What was the single most important thing we could do as a family to improve our health and general well-being? And what would be a good way to better connect to my teenage son?.... Other questions were slightly more political in nature. For years I had been trying to determine (because I am often asked) what is the most important thing an ordinary person can do to help reform the American food system, to make it healthier and more sustainable? Another related question is, how can people living in a highly specialized consumer economy reduce their sense of dependence and achieve a greater degree of self-sufficiency? And then there were the more philosophical questions, the ones I‚Äôve been chewing on since I first started writing books. How, in our everyday lives, can we acquire a deeper understanding of the natural world and our species‚Äô peculiar role in it? (Kindle 96)Pollan goes straight to the horse's mouth to learn about food and cooking. Then he goes to another expert until he begins to work on his own. And he talks about his errors rather than dodging them. For Pollan, mistakes are an opportunity to learn, to understand. He is willing to throw out standard thinking. (Are antibiotics a good thing or not? What about pasteurization?) And, he takes us along for the ride.This is a lovely ride.

This is another excellent offering by Michael Pollan who, since The Omnivore's Dilemma has become my favourite go-to person in all things food related. Admittedly, this was slightly less interesting to me than Pollan's Dilemma, but only because I've already experienced all the joys of being Cooked -- pun intended. For all those who have yet to experience the transformative power of being the master/mistress of one's own hearth, this is a must read. Twice.This is not a recipe book -- far from it, albeit Pollan does throw in a few handy recipes at the very end, based on the four elements he explores: fire, water, air and earth; in essence, the touchstone elements of our universe, and our humanity. This is more a book on the nature of cooking: the whys and wherefores of throwing that first chunk of meat over burning coals, and then of maybe tossing in a tuber or two for good measure. With this simple action, we defined our humanity, Pollan postulates, and it is this that made us stand taller than the apes, once and for all.He also dabbles in the mysticism of cooking, the art of alchemical transformation of both the eaten, and the eater. It is a magical read -- and unlike Pollan's Dilemma which left me never wanting to eat (industrial) food ever again, this book left me ravenous. It is an exceptional testament to why we should all engage in the action of feeding ourselves -- quite literally. The action of going to the market and buying packaged and frozen food-like substances is not cooking, and offers absolutely nothing to our nutritional intake, either chemically or spiritually, Pollan offers. Rather, we need to be closer than arm's length from the veggies and the meats we slide down our gullets: we need to understand how much nourishment actually lies in the act of preparation. Full stars.

Usually I read Michael Pollan to feel distressed (but not awash), and ashamed (but not hopeless). But Cooked is Pollan at his most optimistic. While conscientious as always, he sets out in this book not to acquaint us with the grim facts of our world and its consumers‚Äô decisions; rather, he illustrates the wonders of what we as individuals can do. And what we can do is, obviously: cook. Cook in informed, ambitious ways that link us to the ground, to plants and animals and microbes, to farmers and other producers, and to the people in our lives for whom we cook. This book is part of the antidote to the problems laid out in Omnivore‚Äôs Dilemma and In Defense of Food. It's structured ‚Äúby element,‚Äù wherein Pollan discusses cooking with fire (such as in the barbecue pits of North Carolina), water (braises and pot-cooking), air (with bread-masters from all over) and earth (fermentation.) Fair warning: you find yourself fairly deep in the weeds of the chemical processes of the latter two topics ‚Äì as other reviewers before me have found, these chapters are slower to get through than the first half.Cooked veers toward personal anecdotes, nutrition, chemistry, social history, mythology, and even psychology as necessary. Pollan delivers every discussion with the deftness and humility we expect from him. The writing‚Äôs great, the subjects are varied, and the tone is encouraging. Four solid stars.

Months after finishing this, I feel obligated to bump it up to 5 stars. The Pollanesqe pedantic tone that starts this book off is the only reason that my initial grade was a 4.5 for me, but even that can be kind of endearing... I very regularly felt like I was reading a book by my dad. However, each chapter drew me into a very dreamy, delighted state of reading. I love the path that weaves through research and literature, mixed with Pollan's interactions with fascinating expert cooks as well as his own cooking adventures. I was surprised, inspired, and impressed constantly. This is one book that I'm very happy to own, because even before I finished it I was tempted to refer back to previous chapters as a reference for some real life situation or another. It prompted me to talk about food with people a lot more, and I definitely feel inspired to branch out of my cooking comfort zone. For anyone why might appreciate some background or perspective on the practice of cooking, this is a fabulous choice.I was reading Ecotopia at the same time, a novel that complemented this one very well. Aaaand up next: Moyasimon: Tales of Agriculture, Volume 2, the world of microbes! "Everything is everywhere."

As always, Michael Pollan's new book "Cooked" is an impeccably researched, beautifully written and hands-on journey through the four foundational methods of cooking. Stylistically, it is essentially a mash-up of the styles of his previous books into a snazzy new package - the four pillars of "Botany of Desire," the hands on creation and eating in "Omnivore's Dilemma," and the modern food science vs. traditional eats breakdown of "In Defense of Food." The result is glorious(although at very rare instances almost too brainy). Pollan is a deceptively excellent writer who is capable of making extraordinarily complex concepts and terms accessible to nearly anyone; thus, it is easy to forgive him when he goes a bit awry. I would have liked just a little more description of the work Pollan was doing himself on the cooking; more in depth interviews/apprenticeships, or more recipes. But either way, it's been a while since his last book, and it's good to see Pollan in print again.

I really enjoyed this. I have officially abandoned my Michael Pollan hater stance. I misunderstood him. I might even give Botany of Desire another chance.Now I will ramble:I'm a little jealous that he gets to write these glorified stunt books that are so appealingly nerdy.Now I'm going to start my starter...it's time to take my bread baking to the next level...I don't think I'll be roasting any whole pigs, though. However, listening to that part of the book did take me down memory lane to summer camp as a kid. Every summer we did "Ham in a Pit," and we had to take turns in pairs overnight to keep watch. I don't remember what I actually thought of the resulting food, though. One last thought: germ is my copilot...this book made me really consider dirtiness and how we seem to be really screwing ourselves over. Oh well, we are evolutionary creatures and somehow we will adapt.

I finished listening to the audiobook yesterday and have been considering how to review it. I liked the author's way of encouraging the reader to establish a relationship with food based on "meaning." As well as his invitation to "join the makers of the world."I admired the breadth of his investigation, his knowledge base.The author reads the book. His inflections added meaning, deepened my relationship with the subject matter. Sometimes his calming voice induced drowsiness; after all, the book does not have a rousing plot.But today, I notice that I miss his soothing voice speaking to me of a recently discovered detail of food preparation. It is as if I now set one less place at my table.

This was one of those books where at many points I wished I could be the author! To sample the barbecue in the South, or cheeses in France--oooh!The author uses stories to tell you how he learned about different kinds of foods and their origins. Actually very informative if you want to learn about whole foods and there is much science here. But the sciences in the context of relationships with real people who understand these foods. He hits most of the major types of food that we consume.This book would be an important read for someone who is basically only eating a standard American diet (SAD). It will open your eyes to new food horizons and could help you understand why eating real food makes you much happier and healthier.

Cooking stands for healthy, natural and energy-efficient food intake. Our ancestors started cooking at some point because the addition of heat allowed them to get a lot more nutrients from a lot more natural foods. Unfortunately, we have moved further and further away from it since the global boom in convenience foods. The following still applies today: Those who cook at home with natural ingredients are by far the healthiest (Blinkist, 2020).

A book that inspires, Pollan writes the book around the idea that cooking is much more than just preparing food. He does this by diving into the four elements: fire, water, air and earth. Especially the last two parts that go into the baking of sour dough bread and fermentation are invaluable!

"In Cooked, Michael Pollan explores the previously uncharted territory of his own kitchen. Here, he discovers the enduring power of the four classical elements‚Äîfire, water, air, and earth‚Äîto transform the stuff of nature into delicious things to eat and drink. Apprenticing himself to a succession of culinary masters, Pollan learns how to grill with fire, cook with liquid, bake bread, and ferment everything from cheese to beer.The effects of not cooking are similarly far reaching. Relying upon corporations to process our food means we consume large quantities of fat, sugar, and salt; disrupt an essential link to the natural world; and weaken our relationships with family and friends. In fact, Cooked argues, taking back control of cooking may be the single most important step anyone can take to help make the American food system healthier and more sustainable. Reclaiming cooking as an act of enjoyment and self-reliance, learning to perform the magic of these everyday transformations, opens the door to a more nourishing life."I have to say that I appreciate an author who tells me that I am being subversive or rebellious if I cook. It‚Äôs one of the few forms of rebelliousness to which I wholeheartedly subscribe. Having read Salt Sugar Fat by Michael Moss last year, I been working diligently at eliminating processed foods from my diet‚Äîeasier said than done! Especially when one is also attempting to go gluten-free. I have many happy memories of cooking on the farm where I grew up. We knew the cows that provided our milk, the chickens that laid our eggs and the cattle and pigs that provided each evening‚Äôs main course. Sometimes Mom would even mention them by name as she served up supper. I have been in quest of a real pork chop for some time now and think I have found a butcher shop that provides a product very, very close to my idealized memories. One of the things which struck me when I moved to the city was the lack of taste in the meat and vegetables purchased from the chain grocery stores. Carrots from a chain store are more like wood than like vegetables and tomatoes are hard and tasteless compared to those we grew in our garden (fertilized with well-aged, long composted animal manure).  The problem, for me at least, is one of time. I love to cook and bake‚Äîbut I also work full time and enjoy a busy social life. Having read Cooked, I can see that I will start attempting to schedule more cooking time into my life‚Äîin the past, I have whiled away many happy hours stirring soup pots, checking on oven contents and poking at dough. It‚Äôs time to return that gentle form of rebellion to my life on a regular basis.

This book was received as the result of a Good read giveaway.This was not my average book...but how could I not want to read this as it was about my favourite subject...Food!Pollan covers the four ways of cooking covering fire, water, air and earth, something I had never really thought about before. As someone who cooks 90% of her meals from scratch this had my interest from the first chapter but I wondered how long it would last. After all, what was going to be "news" to me at this point. Well, it turns out...a lot!The book is filled with facts, anecdotes and hands on experiences of the author. Topics covered include real barbequing, braises, bread making and fermentation. I have actually caught myself discussing this book at length with my foodie friends and family. My husband was woken up a few times to hear a paragraph or two that struck a chord with me and I felt the need to discuss or share. He's been patient...but I wonder if it was so I could create the recipes at the back of the book. I will be on the lookout for a crock for some sauerkraut...my hubby's parents make this but now I have a stronger urge to try it out.Interesting, intellectual and inspiring! Well written and well documented.On a final note...it was peanut free so it's safe for everyone. ;)

This was a good book if you're interested in the anatomy of cooking. Michael Pollan is one of my favorite food writers and I always enjoy his books, this one as well. However, this was a little too in depth for me.Michael explores the four realms of cooking in this book, Fire, Water, Air and Earth. For Fire, he uses whole hog barbeque. For Water, he explores braising. For air, his example is baking bread. For Earth he uses fermentation. Basically, he breaks all of these cooking methods down to the smallest elements and builds on it.My final thought on this book is that it was interesting, but if your not really into cooking/food then this book may be too much for you.

In his latest book, Cooked, Michael Pollan serves up another bestseller that looks at the relationships between us and the food we eat. Struck by the realization that ‚Äúthe less cooking we were doing in our own lives, the more that food and its vicarious preparation transfixed us,‚Äù Pollan sets out to explore the art of cooking for himself.Cooked reads like a how-to book for the uninitiated in the kitchen while still providing plenty of more detailed analysis for seasoned cooks. Divided into chapters based on the four classical elements ‚Äì Earth, Water, Air and Fire ‚Äì Pollan personally explores the world of cooking where ‚Äúthe stuff of nature gets transformed into the things we eat and drink.‚ÄùIn each chapter, Pollan learns about a corresponding cooking style: in Fire, he gets grilling lessons from a North Carolina barbecue pit master; in Water, he masters braises; in Air, he experiments with bread baking as he seeks to perfect the perfect sourdough loaf; and finally, in Earth, he explores various types of fermentation including pickling, cheese making and home brewing.Along the way, each of his teachers ‚Äì from ‚Äúthe cheese nun‚Äù with a Ph.D. in microbiology to the ‚Äúmost famous fermentor in America‚Äù ‚Äì is whole-heartedly devoted to his or her craft and, in the end, getting a glimpse into their lives and work is half the fun of the book.I‚Äôve been a Michael Pollan fan since I first cracked the spine of The Botany of Desire more than a decade ago, but even I‚Äôll admit, there are a few points in the narrative where even the most devout reader‚Äôs eyes may start to glaze over‚Ä¶ like when Pollan gets mired in the details of the ‚Äúall-important Lactobacillus sanfranciscensis‚Äù microbe. But only briefly. Because along with straight-up cool science, he also mixes into his narrative a bit of history, art and literature along with a dash of religion (‚Äúbread‚Ä¶ is an everyday proof of the possibility of transcendence‚Äù and sex for good measure (‚Äúa cheese that stinks ‚Äì of manure, of sex ‚Äì offers a relatively safe way for us to flirt with forbidden desires‚Äù).As in his previous books, Pollan extolls the ills (literally) of processed foods and cautions against our over-reliance on corporations, ‚Äúwhose ‚Äòdead food‚Äô is damaging our health and ‚Äòhomogenizing‚Äô our experience.‚ÄùWhen asked why we don‚Äôt spend more time preparing our own meals, apparently most people claim a lack of time. But Pollan points out that, ‚Äúin the last decade or so, we‚Äôve all found two hours a day to be on line outside of work.‚Äù So what gives?Another entire book could be devoted to answering that question, but Pollan doesn‚Äôt take on that job in Cooked. Instead, he argues that we would all do well to start getting reacquainted with our kitchens because ‚Äúcooking is one of the most interesting and worthwhile things we humans do.‚ÄùWhile it may be cheaper and easier to rely on others to provide for our basic needs, ‚Äúto live that way comes at a price, not least to our sense of competence and independence.‚Äù We are so disconnected from the makers of our food, Pollan argues, that we stop thinking about what is actually in the food we eat or where it comes from, much less the labor, money or energy it took to get it onto our plate. Worst of all, we forget that ‚Äúwhat presents itself to us in the marketplace as a product is in truth a web of relationships between people‚Ä¶ and all the other species on which we still depend.‚Äù (Yes, even bacteria.)In the end, Cooked turns out to be a commentary on the way we live. It‚Äôs true, as in his past books, that Pollan is critical of capitalism, and in particular consumerism, as the downfall of democracy and independence in its most literal sense. The antidote (or part of it, anyway) that he offers up here is cooking. To cook, he says, is to reclaim a bit of independence, and perhaps a bit of pride as well. It‚Äôs what separates us from the rest of the natural world and, paradoxically, also what keeps us connected to it.It is also an invitation to modern society (that‚Äôs you and me) to reconnect with the world. It‚Äôs true that few of us have the luxury of spending hours in the kitchen making all of our meals from scratch, but even small culinary contributions help us to reconnect with the natural world around us. As Pollan himself admits, ‚ÄúThe most important thing I learned ‚Ä¶ is how cooking implicates us in a whole web of social and ecological relationships: with plants and animals, with the soil, with farmers, with the microbes both inside and outside our bodies, and, of course, with the people our cooking nourishes and delights.‚Äù And he invites us ‚Äúto alter, however slightly, the ratio between production and consumption‚Äù in our lives.This, he believes, can make a difference. After trying his hand at home brewing, Pollan says, ‚ÄúThe beer in that bottle, I‚Äôm reminded as soon as I brew it myself, ultimately comes not from a factory, but from nature ‚Äì from a field of barley snapping in the wind, from a hops vine clambering over a trellis, from a host of invisible microbes feasting on sugars.‚ÄùSo, if preparing our own home-cooked meals makes us think just a little bit more about the world around us and how, ultimately, we all depend on one another to survive, then certainly a little time with a knife and cutting board won‚Äôt hurt anyone.For novices in the kitchen ‚Äì or first-time Pollan readers ‚Äì Cooked is sure to whet your appetite. For the rest of us, it is the continuation of an ongoing commentary on food, nature and modern society that will not fail to satisfy.

It's difficult to rate a book which was very enjoyable to read, but fraught with quirks of Pollan's writing style and ideology. I'll write this review as a "compliment sandwich." To begin: The chapters on Barbeque (Fire) and Bread (Air) were particularly strong and interesting. I enjoyed the attention he gave to food research at UC Davis, and was glad to see him visit some interesting operations in Yolo County.That being said...Pollan went on several rants only tenuously connected to his topics. Notably, his nostalgia for an agrarian/culinary past that, to use the phrase of Jello Biafra "never existed." Pollan seems oblivious to his own level of wealth and privelege. He emphasizes that he braises "cheap" pieces of meat. Has he compared the price of a brisket to chicken? bologna? a can of beans? He spends days at a time on breads, insisting that he can "get writing done" in between turns and rises. Not everyone is a freelance writer, buddy. Try making a braise and two sourdoughs a week working 9-5.My final criticism is his love of "artisans" while scoffing at anything remotely automated. The problem is that for artisans (of food and everything else) it's a labor of love. An independent baker selling high-end sourdough might be carrying on a food tradition or whatever, but the forklift operator, truck driver, QC specialist, etc. at the Wonder-bread plant he's so quick to dismiss have mentally and physically demanding jobs, with some security, benefits, and disposable income that the starving artist-baker lacks. Does Pollan really envision a bucolic future of nothing but cottage industries? Who would have the income to buy his books?The joke's on him, I took it out of the library.In conclusion- Pollan is an entertaining and gripping writer who has sought out some very interesting characters in the American foodscape. Parts of this book rehash "Omnivore's Dilema," but hey. What can you do? If this were a bad book, I wouldn't have finished it. It's honestly good writing, somewhat choppy, and somewhat obsessive about certain details (raising dough) while ignoring others (Pollan's wealth, and location in the foodie Island of the Bay Area.)

Where has our love gone, Michael? This is the fourth of your books that I've read, which is somewhat fitting, considering your obsession with that number. Second Nature: four seasons, Omnivore's Dilemma: four meals, Botany of Desire: four plants, and with this book four methods of food preparation. I was really excited about a new book from you, as I really enjoyed those three earlier books, despite your tendency to ramble and repeat. When an acquaintance told me how much she enjoyed this book (her first experience with you), I quickly recommended the others and offered to swap her OD for this one. And yet...somehow I just can't get into it. Maybe it's that you're again preaching your slow food message and I've already joined the choir. Maybe it's the current heat wave that makes the subject of cooking less appealing. Maybe it's my stack of novels and lighter non-fiction driving me to distraction. Whatever the cause(s), I'm going to return this copy to the owner (since I've had it for three or four weeks already) and track down a library copy later when cooking and, let's be honest...you, Michael, sound more appealing.Update: it took me almost 7 years, but I finally finished this book! This time, I started with the section on yeast breads, focusing on sourdough. I've experimented with sourdough a couple times since reading Sourdough (and started a new one after finishing the book), so I had more connection to Pollan's experiences than the previous sections. The final section, in which he discusses fermentation (of vegetables, cheese, and alcohol) was also really interesting, especially the American-born nun making traditional cheese in a French convent. For me, the second half of the book was much stronger.

Michael Pollan has written another book about food; this time he researches the history of cooking. He focuses on cooking using the classic elements of fire, water, air, and earth.The section on fire focuses almost exclusively on smoking pork, which is something I enjoy doing. For those of you that have never enjoyed barbeque or smoking, you might not connect with this section like I did. Smoked pork (and chicken) is so good, it is worth the effort to try to perfect your efforts! Take a look at my video on smoking Boston Butts: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2U2--A...I have videos on smoking chicken, salmon filets, and ribs; smoked food is so good and it is fun to connect with nature to prepare food!In the section on cooking with water, Pollan uses a pot to slow cook various delicious dishes. He talked about the time and effort to cook slowly on the stovetop. I had to wonder why he didn't even try using a crockpot or slow cooker! Nonetheless, all of the food sounded really good!The section on air focused on making bread and I almost wanted to make a loaf myself, but then I remembered how addictive bread out of the oven tastes! It was very interesting!Lastly, Pollan focused on "earth" as an element of cooking. Any guess what that could be? I never would have guessed, but it is fermentation. This was my least favorite section because I don't drink, but it was interesting to listen to how Pollan made his own beer. There are many health benefits to eating foods like yogurt that use something like fermentation to grow the cultures. While I eat yogurt every day, I am too much of a wimp to eat the other foods Pollan highlighted.Of course, Pollan could not resist discussing how many people no longer cook--or they heat prepared food and call that cooking. I found all of that fascinating because I do not buy many prepared foods; however, I buy more than I thought!I listened to this audiobook while gardening and loved it!

‚ÄúI found that, much like gardening, most cooking manages to be agreeably absorbing without being too demanding intellectually. It leaves plenty of mental space for daydreaming and reflection.‚Äù ‚Äï Michael Pollan, Cooked: A Natural History of Transformation In Cooked Michael Pollan stays close to his food roots. Similar in theme to: Omnivore's Dilema (Four Meals), In Defense of Food (Food Manifesto), Botany of Desire (Four Plants), Food Rules (Owner's Manual for Food), and Second Nature (Growing Food).Cooked is just another branch on the Phylogenetic food tree for the Pollan's Omnivore, me thinks. Unless, of course, Pollan is going to delve into the proper way to digest, poop, or compost your waste. And... he might just. I am neither a Pollan lover or hater. I've read a bunch of his stuff because it is fast and rather tasty. The problem with Pollan is reading too much of him. His books are a bit full of roughage and eventually too much of his raw idealism or fiber-rich localism gets to you. I think that is the problem with idealists and their genius (genus?). No one can quite live upto the expectations. There just isn't that many locally grown mushrooms, or farmer's markets, or grass-fed organic beef. But education about farming, feasting, and cooking gives us a better sense of both the idea and the real. As long as we are aware of the costs of the way we eat and the way we cook, we are better than we started. The probelm comes in when we believe ALL the hype. As long as you can remain pragmatic about food and Pollan, reading him is a good thing.

Oh my. If there ever was a more tedious and odious exercise in navel gazing, I'd be impressed.I must confess I am baffled by this book. Who is the audience? Is it local foodies who are already converted? In which case, why on earth must the author keep telling us again and again and again how awesome cooking is? We get it, we're the choir, quit your preaching.Or perhaps the audience is the mass produced shrink-wrap microwave toting loner. In which case, hearing someone pontificate on and on and on about the joys of combining heat with edible things is also pointlessly preachy, and Mr Pollan does an abysmal sales job here.The problem is that Mr Pollan has completely and totally run out of things to say. As a result, this book is basically reworking the same sentence over and over again using different combinations of words. So to save the hapless potential victim from having to wade through a few hundred pages of tedium, I'd suggest instead spending the next hour rearranging any subset of these words into as many variations as you can:Heavenly, nature, cooking, is, god, primitive man, plants, aroma, animal sacrifice, producesHour over? You're welcome, I just saved you many more hours of your precious time. You can spend the remaining 5-6 you have left over from not reading this book staring blankly into space, it'll be more meaningful and more likely to result in food related insights.

Don't we all know how to make spaghetti sauce. That how to make bolonaise was a revelation to the author was more telling of him than other informational bits. I have a friend whose husband doesn't know how to turn on his oven. That said, I agree 100 percent with the author about the practice of making meals as being healthy and a good practice. I think he is a fine author and I look forward to his next book. But beware, if you eat enough Carolina BBQ you will end up looking like a hog farmer:)

While I do not eat, and do not advocate eating, many of the items described in this book (meat, cheese, wine...), I am still fascinated by the history of cooking and the processes involved. I really enjoyed the theme of looking at how we use different elements to cook (fire, water, air, earth). It was an enjoyable way to think about the complexity of a task which we used to do daily, but in which industrial societies have been eschewing.
I could go on and on, but it's simple. I love Michael Pollan and everything he has to say.

I have been a big fan of Michael Pollan's books for many years now. So, when this book was published, I really looked forward to reading it. I love his ability to take the science and technical aspects of food and nutrition and make them fascinating.I thought that it was quite appropriate that I read this book during a holiday centered around cooking and eating: Thanksgiving. I love cooking for our family, and I try hard to share that love with our girls, teaching them the simple concepts that I know and showing them how easy it is for a parent who works out of the home to prepare a home-cooked meal using little to no prepared foods. This book really shows the genesis of human cooking and the emotional and primal urges behind what and how we cook. In four different parts (fire, water, air, and earth), he describes different ways we engage with food. I'm not sure what happened - I read the first three parts in the span of just one day, but then I was overwhelmed with other books that I needed to read (for my book club or because they were coming due), and this book was pushed to the side for over a month. Finally, I decided I needed to finish it (I'm sure it's coming due soon!) and I tackled the fourth part in one day. So, while it looks like I took my sweet time, I just had a big break in between.interesting quotes:"Once cooking allowed us to expand our cognitive capacity at the expense of our digestive capacity, there was no going back: Our big brains and tiny guts now depended on a diet of cooked food." (p. 7)"...it will come as no surprise that the decline in home cooking closely tracks the rise in obesity and all the chronic diseases linked to diet." (p. 8)"Killing and cooking a large animal has never been anything but an emotionally freighted and spiritually charged endeavor." (p. 13)"For is there any practice less selfish, any labor less alienated, any time less wasted, than preparing something delicious and nourishing for people you love?" (p. 23)"Cooking puts several kinds of distance between the brutal facts of the matter (dead animal for dinner) and the dining-room table set with crisp linens and polished silver." (pp. 50-51)"...the braise or stew - and particularly the braise or stew of meat that's been cut into geometric cubes and rendered tender by long hours in the pot - represents a deeper sublimation, or forgetting, of the brutal reality of this particular transaction among species." (p. 54)[Samin Nosrat] "'Great cooking is all about the three 'p's: patience, presence, and practice,' she told me at one point. Samin is a devoted student of yoga and she sees important parallels in the mental habits demanded by both disciplines." (p. 141)"If all cooking is a process of transforming the stuff of nature into culture, boiling achieves a more complete transformation of the animal being eaten by (among other things) eliminating any trace of blood." (p. 156)"Who knows what is cooking down there in that scary pot? Bubbling away beneath the murky swamp of sauce might be eye of newt or tail of rat. All pot cooking is occult in some degree, the precise identity of the ingredients hidden from inspection, more or less illegible. 'Mystery meat' is how children refer to it, and rightly so." (p. 159) [our girls often ask what is cooking, and to defray the potential 'ewww, I don't like that'-kind of comment, I ususually just say 'pickled pigs feet. They know that isn't the truth, but they still haven't gotten a satisfactory answer.]"Umami, I realized, is the quasi-secret heart and soul of almost every braise, stew, and soup.I say 'secret' because umami works in somewhat mysterious ways, at least compared with sweet, salt, bitter, and sour. Encountered in the purified form of monosodium glutamate (MSG), glutamate doesn't taste particularly good, or for that matter much like anything at all. To work its magic, umami needs to be in the company of other ingredients. A bit like salt, glutamate seems to italicize the taste of foods, but, unlike salt, it doesn't have an instantly recognizable taste of its own." (p. 169)...the time that people used to spend cooking had a substantial, invisible, and generally positive effect on the way that they and their families ate." (p/ 190)"The study found that when we don't have to cook meals ourselves we eat more of them. As the amount of time Americans spend cooking has dropped by half, the number of meals Americans eat in a day has climbed; since 1977, we've added roughly half a meal's worth of food to our daily intake, most of it in the form of secondary eating." (pp. 191-192)"It seems to me that one of the great luxuries of life at this point is to be able to do one thing at a time, one thing to which you give yourself wholeheartedly.Unitasking." (p. 195)"There's something about a slow-cooked dish that militates against eating it quickly, and we took our time with dinner. Isaac told us about his day; we told him about ours. For the first time all day, it felt like we were all on the same page, and though it would be overstating things to credit that feeling entirely to the delicious braise, it would also be wrong to think that eating the same thing from the same pot, this weeknight communion of the casserole, had nothing to do with it, either." (p. 201)"Some researchers attribute the increase in gluten intolerance and celiac disease to the fact that modern breads no longer receive a lengthy fermentation. The organic acids produced by the sourdough culture also seem to slow our bodies' absorption of the sugars in white flour, reducing the dangerous spikes of insulin that refined carbohydrates can cause." (p. 229)"Going back to ancient Rome, the shade of the bread you could afford precisely indicated your social standing; to know one's place, Juvenal wrote, is 'to know the color of one's bread.' Some historians and anthropologists have suggested the prestige of white flour might also have had a racist tint to it." (p. 256)Sandor Katz: "Did you know you have more bacterial cells in your body than human cells? By a factor of ten! Most of the DNA we're carrying around is microbial DNA, not human. Which raises an interesting question: Who exactly are we?" (p. 300)"One USDA scientist went so far as to claim that there has never been a documented case of food-borne illness from eating fermented vegetables." (p. 312)"For some of us, the deleterious changes to our gut microflora begin at birth, the moment when we are first inoculated with the microbes that will accompany us through life. In utero, our bodies are sterile, but the microbially messy process of vaginal birth exposes the baby to a set of bacteria that immediately begin to colonize its body. Children born by Cesarean section, a far more hygienic process, take much longer to populate their intestinal tract, and never acquire the same assortment of bugs. Some researchers believe this could help explain the higher rates of allergies, asthma, and obesity observed in children born by Cesarean." (pp. 329-330)"Arguing over which culture has the more disgusting delicacy is never going to be very productive. What's interesting here is that so many cultures seem to have one powerful, smelly food that they prize with as much fervor as other cultures despise it...And, just as curiously, the devotees of these strong ferments (or spicy foods) frequently take pleasure in the fact that people from other cultures can't easily choke them down. One of the things a food can do for people is to help define them as a group - we are the people who like to eat rotted shark. It could be that the success of this self-definition depends on other people finding the very same food inedible or disgusting. In the same way that disgust can be used to draw lines between humans and other animals, it can also help draw lines between cultures." (pp. 369-370)"Alcohol is probably the most social drug we humans have. It takes cooperation to produce it, and it is commonly consumed in the company of others." (p. 396)  "The Dionysian magic of fermentation was at once a property of nature and of the human soul, and one could unlock the other." (p. 400)

"...cheese was not so much an invention as a discovery." Yet another masterpiece by Pollan, Cooked is an anthropological, sociological, ethnographical, and humorous narrative just as engulfing as his others. Whether you are a professional chef or a lover of food, this book makes you hungry...for more.
How is Brandon Sanderson considered a better writer by reviews than Michael Pollan?

Pollan has an easy, friendly, and persuasive writing style that managed to draw me away from another book I'd pre-ordered in two formats when Cooked happened to show up on the library hold shelf on the other book's release date.He's best when he's describing his own experiences or describing micro-science to a layman; I found him a little less convincing and slightly on the side of pretentious when he indulged in wide-scale anthropological musings or symbolism along the lines of the four elements he uses to organize this book: fire (barbecue), water (braises), air (bread), and earth (fermented foods, like sauerkraut and beer). I would've been totally fine with section headings with the food name.I was actually surprised to discover that he wasn't already an expert cook; one of his previous books, The Omnivore's Dilemma, had so incisively made the case for eating in a wholesome manner that I'd assumed he had mastered this skill. But this book is the story of his education in various culinary arenas, and as he manages gain tutelage under acclaimed pit masters and bakers, he--and I--became engrossed in his teachers' personal stories and the philosophies that brought them to the mastery of their crafts. (Or the philosophies that developed because of those crafts.)Thus you meet such interesting folks as the "cheese nun," who managed to get the state health inspector to stand down in an otherwise shrill war about raw milk...by a scientific experiment:A nun's habit and a Ph.D. in microbiology--the abbey sent her to the University of Connecticut so that she might better be able to defend her cheese, both from pathogens and from public health authorities--are an unbeatable combination, and, so far at least, the FDA has thought better than to mess with Sister No√´lla, even as the agency has come down hard on many other raw-milk cheese makers.This lovely sly humor is on display several times, often parenthetically, such as when he describes a 300-year-old fermentation pit:The breadfruit in it had been reduced to a sour mush, but it was reported to be "still in edible condition." (You first.)It was interesting how each type of training received different treatment in Pollan's words. The whole pig barbecue ended up making me think more about the sweaty insanity of the chopping block afterward, while trying to feed thousands of hungry people; the year of weekly braising lessons felt prosaic, free of any sudden revelations, although Pollan admits to using what he learned here the most frequently afterward. His description of the bread-making process was utterly engrossing to me (a non-baker from a rice-centric culture), from how he coaxed the starter yeast to the shaping of the dough. His satisfaction rose almost palpably off the bread as he broke the crust of his efforts.And although he dips into scientific explanations whenever he sees fit, pointing out the chemical processes behind caramelization or the nutrients that separate whole wheat flour from white, he delves most deeply into the question of human interaction with internal bacteria: the gut microflora that actually does a lot of the work in keeping us healthy, and how hyper-sanitized environments and antibiotics can devastate this balance. Mary Roach also devotes some time to this in Gulp, and I anticipate a popular science book on the subject soon. Pollan himself doesn't subscribe to the "kombucha will cure AIDS!" line of "let the bacteria grow wild and free!" thinking, but he does make a strong case for eating less sterile food.Note: To his credit, Pollan does acknowledge head-on the gender imbalance that tends to accompany kitchen duties, without letting the discussion devour the book. In general I found him to be cognizant of the larger issues lying behind his personal quest, whether it be food industry lobbying power or cultural values, but touching upon them only gently.Quite a satisfying read, although I think it's best viewed more along memoirish lines than the sort of societal revolution hinted at in The Omnivore's Dilemma. And the ending was more powerful than those of many novels I've read.

‚ÄúCooking is all about connection, I've learned, between us and other species, other times, other cultures (human and microbial both), but, most important, other people. Cooking is one of the more beautiful forms that human generosity takes; that much I sort of knew. But the very best cooking, I discovered, is also a form of intimacy.‚ÄùThis is the third book that I have read by Pollan. He started by writing about gardening and naturally moved on to food and cooking. I started with The Omnivore‚Äôs Dilemma and skipped the gardening books. (I really should go back to those ‚Äì I like reading about gardening even though I don‚Äôt like gardening much.) All three of these books about food have been interesting and enlightening.When I did my review for The Omnivore‚Äôs Dilemma, I wrote, ‚ÄúFor me this is what makes a good read. I get immersed in the book; I learn new things and for at least some of the time I am thinking about the book and author even when I am not reading the book.‚Äù That was true for this book as well. I listened to this and since it took more than thirteen hours, it was with me for a long time. I enjoyed thinking through Pollan‚Äôs theories about how the four elements reflect the four ways of cooking and meeting several chefs, bakers, cheesmakers and brewers. I will look at cooking a bit differently because of this book.
3.5 stars and only because I hold Pollen to a higher standard and liked his other books more.
